ce:section.ce:para: Rapidly growing population, urbanization, and industrialization are some of the causes of the increasing rate of waste generation. It is estimated that the rate of generation for municipal solid waste will be approximately 6.1 million metric tons/day in 2025 (A. Kumar and Agrawal, 2020; A. Singh and Basak, 2018). The quality of waste generation is found to depend on the socio-economic-environmental condition of a nation. However, the developed countries are having the technologies for recovering energy from waste and utilizing waste for developing the new product while in developing countries collection, logistics, awareness and disposal of wastes are problems for effective waste management ( Troschinetz, 2005).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Governance structure for solid waste management
ce:section.ce:para: The Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF) established in 1985 is the nodal organization in the regulatory structure of the central government for solid waste management. The central and state pollution control boards work in coordination for arranging, advancement, coordination and regulating the execution of India's natural and forestry service and projects. For effective management of the generated solid waste various rules are framed under Environment Protection Act-1986. As per the constitution of India, waste management comes under the state list due to its local thus making Urban Local Bodies (ULBs) answerable for the successful management of solid waste. The industrially generated hazardous waste is managed under Hazardous Waste Management Rules, 2008with resulting changes in 2009 and follows a system concerning the Municipal Solid Waste Management. In India, the municipal solid waste is managed at multiple tires includes urban local bodies, state government, and central government. The primary action at the field level is performed by local bodies whereas the state and the central government provide financial support for framing policy. Fig. 31 shows the administrative structure for municipal waste management in India and is discussed as:

ce:section.ce:section-title: Central government
ce:section.ce:para: The central government provides financial support and is responsible for framing policies, makes rules and regulations and preparing guidelines for effective management of waste. It also supports state and local bodies for implementing the improved practices of waste management. The Ministry of Environment, Forest, and Climate Change (MoEFCC) and Ministry of Urban Development (MoUD) are involved in Municipal Solid Waste Management (MSWM) as per the Solid Waste Management rule, 2016. The MoEFCC monitors the execution of the Municipal Solid Waste rules in India while MoUD is responsible for coordinating the administration with state government and Union territory to monitor the practices adopted for the management of solid waste, executing the projects funded, formulation of policies and strategies for solid waste management. It also promotes research and training to the local bodies for improving the practice of managing solid waste. The Ministry of Agriculture (MoA), Ministry of Chemical and Fertilizers, Ministry of New and Renewal Energy (MNRE) and Ministry of Power are the other agencies that come within the structure of the central government for facilitating and assisting for the environment, energy, and infrastructure.

ce:section.ce:section-title: State (provincial) government
ce:section.ce:para: The function of state governments is to coordinate local government and organization with the central and ensure implementation of rules and provisions set by the central government to local bodies working in the sectors sector of municipal waste management. Besides this the state government makes policies and strategies for the state in consultation with local stakeholders for managing waste. The Department of Urban Development monitors the management of municipal solid waste at the state level.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Urban Local Bodies (ULBs)
ce:section.ce:para: Urban local bodies are legal owners of waste for the collection of waste in an authorized area. The Municipal Solid Waste Rule 2016 and 2000 directs the local bodies of urban areas for establishing an effective waste management system and presents an annual report to State Pollution Control Boards and Pollution Control Committee (s). ULBs are responsible for the provision of services of collecting and disposal of waste. These bodies also establish for collection of waste at doorstep, and segregation of waste, facilities for waste - processing, recovery of material and energy, the setting of waste collection facilities, transporting, and disposal. Further, Non-government organization (NGO) and private sectors also work in agreement with municipalities under the terms and conditions and provide services for municipal solid waste management by developing infrastructure from collecting to disposal of waste efficiently and cost-effectively. NGO acts as a communication bridge between the private and governmental realms in promoting awareness program and understand the existing difficulties, gaps, and challenges within communities.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Development of approaches for management of municipal waste in India
ce:section.ce:para: The increasing volume and varieties of generated municipal solid waste has arisen the concerns for economic viability and environmental friendly waste management technologies thus creating a problem for policymakers in the sectors of waste management to device an appropriate waste treatment strategy (Taylor, 2000 ). As it is known that history matters for understanding the development in policy. This section discusses the evolution of policies and approaches for the management of waste in India thus provides an understanding of the interaction between people and society thereby assists in identifying the need for policies and its possible outcomes. The three phases with different goals concentrate on public health and sanitation, protection of the environment, and management of municipal solid waste.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Phase I: public health and sanitation (1950â1980)
ce:section.ce:para: Till late 1980, the significant activity for the management of municipal solid waste in India was driven from the viewpoint of Public Health and Sanitation. The planning commission well known as Niti Aayog focused on the eradication of communicable diseases in India (Finnveden et al., 2013; S. Kumar, 2011). Therefore, the government's aims under Public Health Care and Sanitation were to provide safe drinking waste and sterile removal of waste. After the passing of the first two national 5 years, it was during the third five-year plan when the government motivated the compositing of Municipal solid waste in the civic settlement but fails to meet the expectations due to lack of proper.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Phase II: environmental safety
ce:section.ce:para: The year 1980â2000 focused to adopt measures for controlling environmental pollution. The Bhopal Gas tragedy in December 1984 drew attention towards casualties due to toxic substances. Later, the Ministry of Forest and Environment passes the Environment Protection Act 1986, under this act, the hazardous waste rules, followed by biomedical waste handling rules in 1989. Later, in the year 1998 rules were established to reduce the natural wellbeing dangers. Meanwhile, in mid-1998, the incident of sporadic expansion of the plague in Surat led to realize that ineffective management of solid waste as the major cause of the plague. In the year 1995 Bajaj Committee was formed and several recommendations were made included integration of waste pickers, collection of waste at doorstep, the evolution of recovery centers, developing recycling units, compositing, and imposing charges for collecting wastes. The Municipal Solid waste acts mandated to manage of MSW and instructed the state government to ensure the execution of solid waste management and handling rule 2000.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Phase III: waste management and climatic change (2000âonwards)
ce:section.ce:para: The waste management with environment safety was taken as the primary objective of the government from 1980s to 1990s. As per the report on Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, emission of methane (CH4) due to landfill accounts for 3â19% of the global manmade sources (Suchada et al., 2003 ). National Environmental policy in the year 2006, emerges from various disciplines aims at conserving environment resource and formation of approaches, projects, and ventures for the socio-economic progress of the nation besides, focusing on recycling and strategies for reducing waste.

ce:section.ce:section-title: National urban sanitation policy (2008)
ce:section.ce:para: This policy aims to remove open defecation and covers the aspects of urban sanitation. The policy was prepared by CPHEEO and MoUD for promoting waster, sanitation, and drainage utilities in India.

ce:section.ce:section-title: National action plan for Climate Change (2009)
ce:section.ce:para: The Plan was implemented by eight mission of national action plan and work on climatic variation. The goal of the sustainable domain suggests making improvements in public transport, energy efficiency, and effective solid waste management.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Swachh Bharat Mission (SBM, 2014)
ce:section.ce:para: The Indian government had begun the Swachh Bharat Mission in 2014 intending to eliminate open defecation, develop modern and scientific waste management techniques and eradicating of manual scavenging. The Swachh Bharat Mission had an emphasis on scientific municipal solid waste management (MSWM) and providing scope for modern technological intervention thus bring a change in perspective in the development of Indian Municipal Solid Waste Management. Later, keeping the objective of SBM in view âSolid Waste Management Rules, 2016 was enforced that suggests urban local bodies to adopt a planning process for the formation, execution and revision, MSWM plans.

ce:section.ce:section-title: A seven step approach for solid waste management plan
ce:section.ce:para: Effective solid waste management is a function of municipal thus the municipal authorities require an effective management of solid waste. To achieve this requires systematic development of the MSWM system. Urban local bodies should include the assessment of required tools, processing, transporting and disposal facilities. It is essential to advance a Municipal Solid Waste Management plan under the Solid Waste Management Rules 2016, the strategy and policy of the state on MSWM and the State Sanitation Strategy (SSS) developed under the NUSP. Fig. 32 shows a seven-step approach for the solid waste management plan.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Socio-economic-environmental impact of utilizing solid waste
ce:section.ce:para: Sustainable Solid Waste Management (SSWM) can be attained by pollution abatement, saving resources and energy and imparting benefits to society. The utilization of solid waste as a resource for the development of constructive material can significantly achieve economic sustainability by the generation of secondary material in a cost-effective manner besides providing an opportunity for the setting of new enterprises thus generating employment opportunities. The practices of recycling and utilizing solid waste for construction minimizes the cost for the disposal of solid waste. Safe and healthy working conditions in the sector of waste management achieve social sustainability. Social factors like the prohibition of child labour, protection and freedom of association contribute to social development. The successful recycling and utilization of solid waste achieve environmental sustainability. The manufacturing sectors should promote to development of non-hazardous materials with required workability that produces minimum waste as its end product to ensure green manufacturing. Moreover, the implementation of waste prevention strategies through the consumer side promotes sustainable consumption. Thus, the recycling of solid waste will significantly contribute to the socio-economic- environmental development of a nation as it provides employment, reduction of GHG emission enables energy production and improves public health. Fig. 33 is given below green economy pillars with associated benefits. The benefits associated with the green economy are discussed in detail as:

ce:section.ce:section-title: Economic benefits
ce:section.ce:para: The waste management sector contribute towards job creation, earn income by manufacturing units thus having potential for improving the economy of the nation. The municipal waste management sector covers the largest single budget, and a major portion of the workers are engaged for activities of solid waste management. The waste management sectors are required to change the conventional practices of waste management for promotion of elements of integrated waste management includes a promotion for waste reduction, reuse, recycling, and recovery which results in economic benefit and depletion of the global resource. The value of physical assets can be achieved through an integrated and sustainable waste management approach. Many new services, products and systems in different sectors such as manufacturing, industry, agriculture, transportation, construction, and processing can be achieved through investment in solid waste management. The economic benefit plays a pivotal role in economic development, contributes to reducing poverty and addresses the needs of the countries through non-discriminatory international funds thus establishes the partnership for sustainable development across the globe.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Employment generation
ce:section.ce:para: The approach of developing building material through solid waste generates employment for the successful development of a new practice of solid waste management. Through scavenging in developing countries more jobs will create thus reduces poverty by providing productive employment and decent work for different sectors of workers. The adequate knowledge of newly adopted MSW management techniques provides opportunities for the informal sector to involve in widely varying practices of utilizing waste material. The new job role generation will bring a more skilled pool of laborers that are considered value addition for a country.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Upcycling of waste products
ce:section.ce:para: Upcycling is the transformation or modification of discarded products creatively to develop new products with enhanced quality or value towards the upper end of the innovation scale. The upcycling is beneficial for creating more job opportunities compared to landfill disposal and incineration of waste.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Improves human health
ce:section.ce:para: The poor practices of waste collection, dumping waste in open sites, burning of the waste directly in the atmosphere and improper disposal of waste creates hazards to human health besides creating the problem to the environment and water bodies. The prevention of solid waste from open dumping can be done by using the generated waste directly or indirectly as a resource material that will be effective for improving the health conditions of the workers as well as other human beings by maintaining a clean atmosphere. Forunderstanding the environmental performance of products requires quantification of carbon-di-oxide and methane emissions associated with landfills and assessment of the life cycle. The research on incineration and better energy recovery systems should be encouraged to reduce the emission of toxic bye products and to promote better health conditions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Energy saving
ce:section.ce:para: A significant part of the energy can be saved through the utilization of solid waste as materials for building applications. The energy that can be saved through municipal solid waste components varies differently with regions across the globe. The successful recycling or utilization of solid as a source of raw material will have significant economic impacts. It is estimated that approximately 28% of the total resources are utilized for developing building materials. It is reported that the manufacturing of cement requires approximately 5â8Â MJ/kg of energy while clay bricks and tiles require 2â7Â MJ/kg of energy. Further, 30% of energy can be saved by the addition of 25% of fly ash or 40% of blast furnace slag in Portland-pozzolana. A similar study reports that 15% of the energy required for burnt clay bricks, can be saved with the incorporation of 25% of flay ash with clay soil (Shukla et al., 2020). Moreover, the use of rice husk and groundnut for making particleboard saves about 20% of energy. The agro-industrial wastes like asbestos fiber, timber, and mica could be an alternative material for various building materials and save a significant amount of energy. Thus, it suggests the solid wastes are having quite potential for developing various building materials besides saving energy.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conclusions
ce:section.ce:para:
The increasing rate of solid waste generation is noticeably a worldwide environmental concern. This review explores the recycling potential of solid for successful building material. It is from the literature that various characterization techniques are extremely vital for recycling material into a successful product. The method of utilizing solid waste in construction industries reduces the requirement for raw material besides providing a solution to environmental hazards caused by the disposal of wastes. It reduces overburden on natural resources and maximizes the economic and technical aspects of municipal solid waste. Moreover, analysing the studies in terms of collected data, research gap, scope and limitations, and critical indicators employed assessed the adaptability of developed methods regarding the recycling potential of solid waste as materials for building applications. In particular, the study found that:
1.
Growing population, urbanization, industrialization, etc. are the causes for rapidly increasing rate of the waste generation thus creating socio-economic and environmental problems. The global data had showed an urgent need for strategies to treat the increasing rate of MSW generation.
2.
The volume and characteristic of generated waste vary with regions thus there doesn't exist any waste to energy conversion technology that is feasible for every kind of waste treatment. The review suggests the adoption of one of the elements of Integrated Waste Management i.e., recycling, for management of solid waste and examines recycling of the solid waste for building construction as a viable approach for solid waste management.
3.
There exists a gap in altitude and behaviour for waste management among the different communities of the globe and identifies lack of education, awareness for waste management, economic obstruction, insufficient service, operational inadequacy, and lack of practices for reducing waste at the source.
4.
The development of practices and technologies of utilizing municipal solid waste as building materials generates employment, provides an opportunity to earn a livelihood and reduces the cost of building construction and requirement of raw materials besides improving the health of the public and environment thus contributes for socio-eco-environmental development.
5.
The local authorities should ensure for proper execution of the regulation and policies framed by the ministry working in the demesne of environment and waste management.
6.
The literature studies show that significant demonstrations had been made by the researchers, but they are rarely adopted by the communities due to certain constraints.
7.
It is possible to utilize solid waste as raw material for construction building materials, also with the combined effort of government and the public can mitigate the problem of generated solid waste besides providing newer materials for construction that would result in green construction.
